I should stay far away from childish people.
When I come across them, I should be happy to please them.
Without being very familiar,
I should treat them well just like any ordinary person.

Like a bee taking nectar from a flower,
I should accept only what is for the dharma.
I should remain unfamiliar,
As if they were someone I had never met before.

‘I have lots of possessions and respect.
I am really popular.’
If I hold on to such thoughts,
My death will be horrible.

Therefore, whatever it is
That this utterly confused mind desires,
Along with it comes
A thousand sufferings.

Therefore, the wise don’t have desires.
Fear comes from desire.
Since it is the nature of things to be let go of,
I will be firm and recognize this well.

I may have many possessions,
And I may be famous and praised,
But these possessions and fame—
I don’t know what will become of them.

Why does someone’s praise please me,
When there is someone else to criticize me?
Why does someone’s criticism displease me,
When there is someone else to praise me?

If even the Conqueror could not satisfy
The various inclinations of sentient beings,
What can one say of a wretch like me?
Therefore, I will give up thinking about worldly people.

They look down on those who have no possessions,
And complain about those who have them.
Since they are so difficult to get along with,
How can they bring me any joy?

The Tathāgata said,
‘Since the childish are not happy
Unless they are benefitting themselves,
The childish are friends to no one.’

In the forest, the deer, birds
And trees do not speak unpleasantly.
When will I come to live among
Such good company?

Staying in caves or deserted shrines,
Or at the foot of a tree—
I will not look back
But will be free from attachment.

When will I come to live
In naturally spacious places,
Not claimed by anyone as their own,
Free to do as I please, without attachment?

Having just a begging bowl and a few things,
Wearing clothes not wanted by anyone,
Not even having to conceal this body—
When will I come to live without worry?

When will I go to the burial ground, where,
Between my body and those heaps of bones,
There is no difference
In our subjection to disintegration?

That is where this body of mine will end up,
With a stink so putrid
That not even the wolves
Will want to go near it.

If the very flesh and bones
That comprise my body
Must come apart,
What can be said of friendships?

When we are born, we are born alone.
When we die, we die alone.
If they cannot relieve us of our burden of suffering,
What do friends do but create obstacles?

As travellers on the roads
Take their places to stay,
So, on the paths of conditioned existence,
All take their places of birth.

While everyone is completely grief-stricken,
Four pallbearers carry someone away.
Before that time comes for me,
I will go to the forest.

I will stay alone in isolation,
Somewhere without friends or antagonists.
When I die, since they will already think of me as dead,
I won’t cause them any distress.

And since they won’t be around me,
Being miserable and causing problems,
Nobody will be able to distract me
From mindfulness of the Buddha and so on.

Therefore, I will go to live
In the bright, beautiful forest where,
With few problems, happy and content,
All disturbances will be pacified.

Giving up all other purposes,
I will endeavour single-mindedly
To place my mind in meditative equipoise
And subdue it.

In this world and in the next,
Our desires bring us only ruin.
Here, we are killed, imprisoned and broken,
And in the next, we go to the hells.

To get her, you had entreated her,
With messengers, male and female,
Without any thought
For nonvirtue or shame.

You would do things that terrified you,
Waste your wealth and,
When she was finally in your arms,
Were overjoyed with what was really

Nothing but a skeleton,
With neither autonomy nor self.
But because of your intense desire and attraction to her,
You did not go beyond suffering.

At first, you tried to get her
To raise her face to you but, modestly, she looked down.
Whether anyone could see her or not,
She covered her face with a veil.

That face, which so concerned you,
Is right there before you now,
For the vultures have stripped it bare—
So why do you run away?

When someone looked at her,
You would completely shield her face from him,
But now that the vultures are eating that face away,
Why, selfish, don’t you protect it?

Seeing this pile of flesh
Being eaten by vultures and other creatures,
Why don’t you go and present to their food
Those flower garlands, sandalwood and ornaments?

If you are afraid of a mere pile of bones,
Even though it cannot possibly move,
Why are you not frightened
By something that stirs like a zombie?

You wanted it when it was covered.
Why don’t you want it now it is uncovered?
If you have no need of it now,
Why did you want it then?

If excrement and saliva
Come from the same source—food,
Why do you love her saliva,
But not her excrement?

You don’t have any love for your pillow
Of soft cotton but,
Telling yourself she doesn’t really stink,
Your desire confuses you about what is impure.

Those confused, desirous wretches,
Though their pillows are soft,
Get angry, saying,
‘I can’t copulate with this!’

If you aren’t attracted to impurity,
Why do you embrace
A cage of bones joined by ligaments,
And plastered over with flesh?

You yourself have plenty of impurity,
Which you continually have to experience,
And yet you hungrily chase after the filth of others
Though they, too, are bags of impurity.

‘It’s just their flesh I enjoy.’
If that is what you want to see and touch,
Do you want it in its natural state,
Devoid of a mind?

The mind that you desire
Cannot be seen or touched,
So it makes no sense to want to copulate with it.
What can be seen and touched is not conscious.

It is unremarkable to misunderstand
The impure nature of other bodies,
But it is very remarkable to misunderstand
The impurity you yourself have.

Not noticing a young lotus flower,
Spreading its petals in the sunlight on a cloudless day,
Why is the mind so attracted to impurity,
And drawn to cages of impurity?

If you don’t want to touch
An area covered in excrement,
Why do you want to touch
The body it issued from?

If you are not attracted to impurity,
Why do you want to copulate with the body parts of others,
Which came from an impure place,
And developed from an impure seed.

You are not attracted to
A tiny grub, born on excrement.
Yet, you are attracted to bodies which have many natural impurities,
And are even born from impurities.

Not only do you not mind
The impurity of your own body,
But, wanting even more impurity,
You desire other bags of impurity, too.

When pleasing substances like camphor,
Rice or cooked vegetables
Are spat out after chewing,
Even the ground is considered dirty.

Though such impurity is quite obvious,
If there are any doubts about it,
Take a look at the bodies in the cemetery.
You can see even more impurity there.

If someone’s skin were to be peeled away,
You would be completely horrified.
You know this, so how can you
Ever be attracted to such a thing again?

Scents applied to the body
Are of sandalwood and so forth, nothing else.
Why are you attracted to things
That smell of something else?

The body’s natural smell is awful.
Isn’t it right not to be attracted to it?
Why do the worldly, craving something meaningless,
Daub it with a fragrance?

For, if the fragrance is that of sandalwood,
How could it come from the body?
Why are you attracted to things
That smell of something else?

The body in its natural state,
With long hair and nails,
With stinking, grey teeth, covered with foul-smelling dirt,
And naked, is actually frightening.

Why make such an effort to clean up
Something that is like a weapon for wounding me?
This world is in chaos with lunatics,
Frantic in their self-centred confusion.

Having seen a few skeletons in the cemetery,
You felt revulsion.
So are you happy in this cemetery city,
Full of moving skeletons?

In this way, you cannot have
Such impurity without paying a price.
For those who get it, exhaustion
And agonies such as those of hell ensue.

Children cannot amass any wealth,
And the young cannot enjoy it.
When life is wasted chasing them,
What use are those desires to the old?

Some miserable people, full of desire,
Are completely worn out at the end of a long day.
They come home and collapse,
Their lifeless bodies sleeping like the dead.

Some are afflicted by travelling,
And have to suffer being far from home.
Though they miss their families,
They will not see them for years on end.

Some confused ones, wanting to help themselves,
Sell whatever they have but,
Without getting what they wanted, are driven aimlessly
By the winds of others’ karma.

Some sell their own bodies,
And are helplessly exploited by others.
If his wife should give birth, she must do so
At the foot of a tree or in whatever remote place she finds herself.

Fools, deceived by their desire,
Want a livelihood and, thinking they will make a living,
Join the army, though they are afraid of dying,
Or enter into servitude for money.

Some desirous people can be seen with broken bodies,
Or impaled upon stakes,
Or pierced by blades,
Or even burned.

Due to the anxieties of getting, keeping and losing wealth,
Understand that its problems are endless.
Those who become distracted by attachment to wealth
Have no opportunity for liberation from the sufferings of saṃsāra.

Those who have desire for such things
Will have many problems and little satisfaction.
They are like beasts pulling a wagon,
Able to eat just a few mouthfuls of grass.

For the sake of something that gives little satisfaction
And which so common that even animals can get it,
Those tormented by their karma waste the magnificent freedoms and endowments
That they had acquired with such difficulty.

The objects of desire will inevitably perish,
But I will fall into the hells and so forth.
For the sake of something not very important,
I have been wearing myself out.

If buddhahood itself can be attained
With just a millionth of that difficulty,
Having desire is much more suffering
Than practising the bodhisattva conduct but without any enlightenment.

When one thinks about the sufferings of the hells,
The dangers of weapons, poisoning, fires, ravines
And enemies are nothing
Compared to the objects of desire.

Disillusioned with the objects of desire,
I will develop joy in solitude.
In peaceful forests,
With no conflict or defilements,

Fortunate ones, cooled by sandalwood moonlight,
Stroll and contemplate the benefit of others,
Among wondrous palaces of immense rocks,
As a silent, soothing forest breeze blows.

In an empty hut, at the foot of a tree or in a cave,
They stay as long as they want.
They have left behind the sufferings of masters and protection and,
Not reliant on anyone, live carefree.

Free and without attachment,
Not tied to anyone,
They live with a contentment and happiness
That even Indra would have difficulty finding.

Having considered how solitude
Has such good qualities,
I should pacify conceptual discrimination
And meditate on bodhicitta.

Equalizing self and others
Is the first thing to try and cultivate.
Since everyone is the same when it comes to happiness
And suffering, I should look after them as I do myself.

Just as the whole body should be protected,
Though it has many different parts—hands and so on,
So different beings, whether happy or suffering,
All want to be happy, just as I do.

Though my suffering doesn’t harm
The bodies of others,
Nevertheless, it is my suffering,
And clinging to it as ‘mine’ makes it intolerable to me.

Similarly, though the suffering of others
Does not befall me,
Nevertheless, it is my suffering,
And clinging to it as ‘mine’ will make it hard for me to tolerate.

I should expel the suffering of others
Because it is suffering, like my own suffering,
And I should benefit others
Because they are sentient beings, like I am.

When you and I
Are the same in wanting to be happy,
What is so special about me
That I work only for myself?

When you and I
Are the same in not wanting to suffer,
What is so special about me
That I look after myself and not you?

‘Their suffering doesn’t hurt me,
So why should I care about them?’
Future sufferings don’t hurt you either,
So why protect yourself from them?

To think, ‘I’m the one who will experience it’,
Is a mistake.
It is someone else who dies after this,
And someone else again who is born.

‘The ones with the suffering
Should look after themselves.’
The suffering of the feet is not that of the hands,
So why should the hands protect them?

‘It may not be right,
But I do it out of self-clinging.’
Neither self nor other is right:
You should try to give them both up.

A ‘stream’ and a ‘composite’ are false,
Like a string of beads or an army.
Suffering is not owned by anyone,
So, who should be the one to remove it?

Sufferings have no owner:
None of them is unique.
If it is suffering, it should be eradicated.
Why be inconsistent about this?

There is no disagreement about the reason
For preventing everyone’s suffering.
If you prevent it at all, prevent it for all.
Otherwise, don’t do it for anyone.

‘Compassion will bring me a lot of suffering,
So why should I develop it?’
If you think about the sufferings of living beings,
How can compassion be considered a lot of suffering?

If one person’s suffering
Can stop many sufferings,
A kind-hearted person would take on that suffering
For his own sake and the sake of others.

It was for this reason that Supuśpacandra,
Though he knew the king would harm him,
Did not evade his own suffering
In order to exhaust many sufferings.

One who cultivates this in their being,
With the joy of pacifying the suffering of others,
Would enter the Avīci Hell
As if they were diving into a lotus pool.

When sentient beings are completely liberated,
It is an ocean of joy.
Is that not enough?
What use is it wanting my own liberation?

In this respect, though I am benefitting others,
I will do it without conceit or thinking it is a big deal.
By taking joy solely in their benefit,
I will not expect the ripening of any results.

Therefore, just as I protect myself
From the slightest criticism,
So I should have a protective attitude towards others,
And a compassionate intent.

Just as out of habit I regard
The drops of semen and blood
Of others as ‘myself’,
Even though they have no substance,

Why don’t I regard the bodies of others
As ‘myself’ in the same way, too?
Nor should it be hard to see
My own body as theirs, too.

Having recognized that self is defective,
While others are an ocean of good qualities,
I should completely abandon self-clinging
And practise embracing others.

Just as I regard my hands, etc.
As parts of my body,
Why don’t I regard embodied beings
As limbs of one life?

Just as habituation has brought about
The idea of self for this selfless body,
Why should habituation not create
The same idea about sentient beings?

Though I might benefit others in this way,
I will not have conceit or think it is a big deal,
Like not expecting a reward
After eating my own food.

Therefore, just as I protect myself
From the slightest criticism,
So I should have a protective attitude towards beings,
And cultivate a compassionate intent.

The protector Avalokiteśvara,
Out of great compassion
Blessed even his own name
To dispel the fear of crowds.

I shouldn’t turn away from difficulty.
Just hearing someone’s name might have once frightened me but,
By the power of habituation,
I will come to be disappointed at their absence.

Whoever wants quickly
To protect himself and others
Should practise the holy secret:
Exchanging self and others.

Out of attachment to my body,
I am frightened by the slightest threat.
Who would not resent as an enemy
A body which creates so much fear?

Wanting to alleviate the body’s
Hunger and thirst, or its sickness,
Someone kills a bird, fish or deer,
Or lies in ambush by the roadside.

For the sake of wealth and status,
Someone kills his father and mother,
Or steals the offerings made to the Three Jewels and,
Because of this, burns in the Avīci Hell.

Who, then, would be wise
To cherish, protect and lavish gifts upon that body?
Who would not see it as their enemy,
And regard it with contempt?

‘If I give this, what will I have?’
Thinking of one’s own benefit is the way of demons.
‘If I keep this, what will I give?’
Thinking of the benefit of others is the dharma of the gods.

If I harm others for my own sake,
I will be tormented in the hells and so forth but,
If I am harmed for the sake of others,
I will attain everything I could possibly want.

If I desire a high status for myself,
I will go to the lower realms, lowly and stupid but,
If I wish it for others,
I will obtain a happy rebirth and every honour.

If I use others for my own sake,
I will come to know servitude and so forth myself but,
If I work for the sake of others,
I will come to experience a high status and so forth.

Whatever happiness there is in this world
All comes from wanting others to be happy.
Whatever suffering there is in this world
All comes from wanting one’s own happiness.

Does this need to be explained any further?
Just look at the difference between
The childish, who pursue their own benefit,
And the Buddhas, who carry out the benefit of others.

If I do not actually exchange
My happiness for the suffering of others,
Not only will I not attain buddhahood but,
Even in saṃsāra, I will find no happiness.

Even apart from my future lives,
Nothing would get done in this life:
Servants would fail to do their work
And masters would refuse to pay them.

Completely discarding the abundant joy and contentment
Of achieving both visible and invisible happiness
And, instead, being a cause of suffering for others,
In confusion, I am bringing unbearable suffering upon myself.

All the dangerous forces in the world
And as much fear and suffering as there is,
Come from self-grasping,
So what good is this great demon to me?

If I don’t give it up completely,
I cannot avoid suffering,
Just as if I don’t put out a fire,
I cannot avoid being burnt.

Because it will, in this way, pacify harm to myself
And pacify the sufferings of others,
I will give myself up for others,
And embrace others as I did the self.

‘I am under the control of others.’
With this conviction, mind,
You will now have no thought
Other than benefitting all sentient beings.

Since my eyes, etc. are controlled by others,
It is not right for them to accomplish my benefit.
Since my eyes, etc. are for their benefit,
It is not right for them to do any harm.

Therefore, I should put sentient beings first.
Anything I see on my body
Should be taken away from it
And used to help others.

Taking my inferiors, etc. as self;
And taking self as other,
With a disinterested mind,
I will meditate on envy, competitiveness and pride.

He gets respect, but I don’t.
I don’t have any wealth like his.
He is praised while I am criticized.
He is happy while I am suffering.

I have to work
While he sits back comfortably.
He is renowned in the world as great,
While I am his inferior, with no good qualities.

How can I have no good qualities?
Everyone has good qualities.
Compared to some, he is inferior.
Compared to some, I am superior.

My degenerate view, moral conduct and so on
Are not my fault but are due to the power of the defilements.
He should do whatever he can to help me;
I accept this may cause some pain.

Why does he not help me,
But only criticize me?
What use are his qualities to me,
When he keeps them for himself?

He has no compassion for beings
Living precariously at the mouth of the lower realms.
Conceited in how his own qualities compare to others,
He wants to outrival the learned.

Though he is regarded as my equal,
I should be his superior,
So I will acquire wealth and respect
Even if it brings conflict.

I will do what I can to make my own good qualities
Apparent to the whole world,
And make sure nobody has heard of
His good qualities.

I will hide my own faults
And everyone will praise me instead of him.
From now on, I will get all the wealth,
And they will respect me instead of him.

I will happily watch for a long time,
As he is unfairly treated.
Everyone will laugh at him
And we will all agree he is contemptible.

I hear this miserable wretch
Is trying to compete with me.
How can he equal me in learning, wisdom,
Looks, intelligence or wealth?

When they hear of my good qualities,
Which everyone talks about,
I will really enjoy the pleasant feeling
Of a tingling sensation.

In case he has something of his own,
As long as he works for me,
I will force him to give it to me,
And he will get just enough to live on.

I will constantly deprive him of happiness
And inflict harm upon him.
While I have been wandering in saṃsāra,
He has hurt me hundreds of times.

Wanting to benefit yourself, mind,
Countless aeons have been wasted.
Now you are exhausted,
And you have achieved only suffering.

Those who decisively engage
In truly benefitting others,
In future will, as the Sage has incontrovertibly said,
Know the excellence of having done so.

If, in the past, you had acted this way,
Your current predicament,
Devoid of the magnificent bliss of buddhahood,
Would not have come about.

Therefore, just as you grasp as self
The drops of semen and blood from others,
So you should regard all others as self
Through habitual practice.

On the lookout for others,
If you see something on the self’s body,
Steal it from him
And use it to benefit others.

‘I am happy but others are unhappy.
I have a high status but others are low.
I help myself but never others.’
Why am I not envious of myself?

I will go without my own happiness,
And instead take on the sufferings of others.
I will examine my own faults, thinking,
‘What should I do here?’

Although others have their faults,
I will treat them as my own faults but,
When I do something even slightly at fault,
I will admit it openly.

Letting the reputations of others
Eclipse my own,
I will work for the benefit of all
Like the lowliest servant.

Imperfection is in my nature,
So don’t praise me for some accidental quality.
Should I even have such a quality,
Nobody needs to know about it.

In short, let whatever harm
You have selfishly inflicted on others
Fall upon yourself
For the sake of sentient beings.

Don’t be overbearing,
With an arrogant manner.
Have manners like a new bride:
Be modest, apprehensive and restrained.

That which is to be kept
And that which is to be avoided
Should be under your control.
Transgressions should be subjugated.

Despite being given such advice,
If you, mind, do not practise accordingly,
You will be the source of the faults,
So it is you who will be subjugated.

Though you have destroyed me,
That is in the past. That time is over.
Now I have seen you, where can you go?
I am going to completely crush your arrogance.

Also, give up any idea
Of benefitting yourself.
Since I have handed you over to others,
Stop complaining and get to work.

In case I lose concern
And fail to hand you over to sentient beings,
Then no doubt you will hand me over
To the guardians of hell.

That is how you have betrayed me before:
Handing me over to long-lasting misery.
Recalling my past resentments,
I will crush you, selfish mind.

If I want joy,
I should not pursue my own joy.
If I want protection,
I should always protect others.

The more I look after
This body,
The more sensitive
It becomes.

Having become so sensitive,
The whole world will not be enough
To fulfil its wishes,
So who could give it what it wants?

Unable to get what it wants,
The defilements grow and the mind deteriorates
But, for someone who does not need anything,
There is no end to his riches.

Therefore, I should not allow opportunities
For the body’s desires to grow.
Not grasping attractive objects—
That is the best possession to have.

In the end, this unclean form
Cannot prevent itself turning to dust.
Unable to move and moved only by others—
Why grasp that as ‘me’?

What use is this contraption to me,
Living or dead?
What is special about this particular lump?
Why don’t I overcome pride?

By cherishing the body,
I have gathered suffering for no purpose,
So why have attachment and aggression
Over something indistinguishable from a block of wood?

Whether I am attending to its needs
Or it is being eaten by the vultures, etc.
It feels neither attachment nor anger,
And yet I have attachment to it.

If it feels no
Anger when criticized
Nor happiness when praised,
What am I tiring myself out for?

‘I am attached to this body
Because I am close to it.’
Since everyone is attached to their own body,
Why have I no joy for them?

Therefore, I will give up this body
Without any attachment for the benefit of beings.
Therefore, though it has many faults,
I will keep it for use in this work.

Therefore, no more childish behaviour.
I will follow the wise—
Remembering their words on concern,
I will fight off sleep and lethargy.

Like the great, compassionate sons of the conquerors,
I will bear whatever must be done.
If I don’t work at this night and day,
When will my suffering ever end?

Therefore, in order to dispel the obscurations,
I will withdraw my mind from its mistaken ways,
And continually rest in equipoise
Upon the perfect object.

All of these factors were taught
By the Sage for the sake of wisdom.
Therefore, those who wish to pacify sufferings
Should develop wisdom.

Relative and ultimate: these are the two truths.
The ultimate is not within
The domain of conceptual thought.
Conceptual thought is said to be relative delusion.

We can see two types of people:
Buddhists and ordinary people.
The ordinary, worldly people
Are refuted by lower Buddhist schools.

The Buddhists, too, have distinct schools of conceptual thought,
Of which there are higher and lower,
Who debate and agree upon examples,
While not abandoning conceptual thought in order to achieve the results.

Worldly people see objects as existent
And discriminate them as reality,
Not as illusion-like. Therefore, on this,
Buddhists and worldly people are in dispute.

When there is perception of forms and so forth,
That is a consensus, not a valid cognition.
If the consensus is that something unclean is clean,
Then it is a delusion to accord it.

For the sake of introducing the worldly,
The protector taught in terms of existence.
In suchness, there is not even momentary existence.
‘Then momentariness cannot be a relative truth.’

There is no error, for it is the Buddhist’s relative.
In comparison to the worldly, it is seeing reality.
Otherwise, the ascertainment that women are impure
Would be refuted by the worldly.

The merit in relation to the illusion-like Conqueror
Is just as if he really existed.
‘If sentient beings are illusory,
How are they reborn after death?’

For as long as the conditions are assembled,
Even an illusion will continue to arise.
So how could sentient beings really be existent
Just because their continuity lasts for a long time?

When illusory beings are killed,
There is no nonvirtue, because there was no mind.
Merit and nonvirtue originate
With those who possess an illusory mind.

Since mantras and so on do not have that power,
Illusory minds do not arise from them.
Having arisen from a variety of conditions,
Illusions will vary too,

But nowhere is there a single condition
With the ability to create them all.
‘The ultimate is nirvāṇa.
Saṃsāra is relative truth. In this way,

If he is in saṃsāra despite being a Buddha,
What is the point of the bodhisattva conduct?’
If the continuity of conditions is not interrupted,
Even an illusion will not be dispelled.

If the continuity of conditions is interrupted,
It will not arise, even as relative.
‘If even delusion does not exist,
What perceives the illusion?’

Since for you the illusion does not exist either,
What do you perceive?
‘They exist as if they were external,
But they are representations, which are mind itself.’

If the illusion is mind itself,
Then what is seen by what?
The protector of the world has taught
That mind does not see mind.

Just as the blade of a sword
Cannot cut itself, so it is with the mind.
‘It is like a lamp—self-illuminating.’

That lamp could never be illuminated,
For it was never cloaked in darkness.
‘The blue of a crystal, etc. depends on something external,
While naturally blue objects do not depend on anything.

Similarly, seeing is in some cases other-dependent,
And in other cases, independent.’
Something already blue
Cannot make itself blue.

A lamp, when cognized by a cognition,
May be designated ‘that which illuminates’,
But what do you claim cognizes
The mind as ‘illuminating itself’?

If it is not seen by anyone,
Then whether it is illuminating or not
Is like the looks of a barren woman’s daughter—
Discussing it is meaningless.

‘If self-awareness did not exist,
How could consciousness be remembered?’
Memory comes from its connection to another experience,
Like deducing a rat bite from an infection.

‘Since, under the right conditions, a mind can see
That of others, how can it not see itself?’
Through applying the eye lotion of accomplishment,
One will see a vase and not the eye lotion itself.

Cognitions of seeing and hearing
Are not the objects of negation here.
Here, we are preventing the cause of suffering:
Their discrimination as real.

Illusions are not other than mind
But you do not think of them as identical.
If they were real, they would have to be other than mind but,
If they are not other than mind, they cannot be real.

An illusion is not true, yet it is seen.
So it is for the mind which sees.
‘Saṃsāra must have an existent basis.
Otherwise, it would be like space.’

If the nonexistent were to rest on the existent,
Could it then start to function?
Your mind would be unaided
And completely solitary.

Being free from dualistic perception,
Everyone would be an enlightened Tathāgata.
So what is achieved
By designating it mind only?

‘How will your illusion-like understanding
Stop the defilements?
When an apparitional woman is conjured,
Desire for her arises even in her creator.’

That creator has not abandoned the imprints
Of the defilements in her appearance.
Thus, when he sees her,
The imprints of emptiness are weak.

By meditating on the imprints of emptiness,
The imprints of reality will be abandoned.
By meditating it is nothing whatsoever,
That, too, will then be abandoned,

For when one thinks, ‘It does not exist’,
There is no conception of an analysandum.
Its unreality has then lost its basis,
So how can it remain before the conceptual mind?

When neither existence nor nonexistence
Remain before the mind,
Since there is no other category at that time,
There is a complete non-conceptual pacification.

Just as wish granting jewels
And wish fulfilling trees fulfil hopes,
So, too, the conquerors appear
By the power of trainees and aspiration prayers.

For example, when the creator
Of a shrine of Garuḍa had passed away,
The shrine still pacified poisons and so on,
Long after his death.

By holding the bodhisattva conduct,
The shrine of the Conqueror is built,
So even after the bodhisattva’s nirvāṇa,
The benefit of others continues.

‘How could making offerings to
Someone without a mind have any result?’
Remaining in the world and passing into nirvāṇa
Were taught to be equivalent.

Whether relative or in suchness,
According to the scriptures, there is a result,
Just as, for example, there is a result
In offering to a real Buddha.

‘One is liberated by seeing truth,
So what is the point of seeing emptiness?’
The scriptures teach
No enlightenment without this path.

‘The Mahāyāna is not established.’
Why are your scriptures established?
‘Because they are established for both of us.’
They were not established for you at first,

And whatever conditions gave you confidence in them,
We have such conditions in the Mahāyāna, too.
If truth is the belief of any two others,
The Vedas and so forth would also be true.

‘But the Mahāyāna is disputed.’
Your scriptures are also in dispute—with those of the tīrthikas,
As well as with certain other śrāvaka scriptures.
Therefore, you should abandon them.

‘The root of the doctrine is the monk.’
It is difficult to be such a monk.
A nirvāṇa for the perceptual mind
Is also difficult to attain.

‘One is liberated by abandoning the defilements.’
Then liberation would happen immediately,
Yet one sees the power of karma
Even though there are no defilements.

‘That is only temporary,
For there is no direct cause—craving.’
They do have craving, though it is without defilements,
For don’t they still have fundamental delusion?

By the condition of sensation, there is craving,
And they still have sensation.
The objectifying mind
For such people, still remains.

Minds without emptiness
May cease, but they will arise again,
Like even settling without formations.
Therefore, meditate on emptiness.

If you accept the words included in the sutra collection
As the Buddha’s teachings,
Why do you not accept the majority of the Mahāyāna
Which is the same as your sutras?

If all are rejected as the Conqueror’s teachings
Due to a single point not being included,
Why would all not be accepted
Due to a single point corresponding to your sutras?

If the depths of these words were not fathomed
Even by someone like Mahākāśyapa,
Who should reject them
For their not being understood by you?

For the sake of those suffering due to confusion,
One remains in saṃsāra,
But is freed from the extremes of desire and fear:
This is the result of emptiness.

Thus, it is incorrect to so criticize
The doctrine of emptiness.
Therefore, you should meditate on emptiness
Without entertaining doubts.

Emptiness is the antidote to the darkness
Of the obscurations of defilements and cognizables.
How can those who wish to attain omniscience
Not hurry to meditate on it?

Something that produces suffering
Should produce fear,
But emptiness pacifies suffering,
So why should it produce fear?

If there were something that was ‘I’,
You would be right to be afraid.
But since there is no such thing as ‘I’,
What is there to be afraid of?

Self is not the teeth, hair or nails.
It is neither the bones nor blood.
It is neither the mucus nor phlegm,
Nor is it the lymph or pus.

Self is neither the fat nor sweat.
Neither the lungs nor liver are the self,
Nor are any of the other inner organs.
Self is neither the excrement nor urine.

Neither the flesh nor skin are the self,
Nor are warmth or respiration the self.
The orifices are not the self,
And none of the six consciousnesses are the self either.

If the cognition of sound were immutable
The sound would always be perceived.
If there is no cognizable, how is that awareness?
Why call this ‘cognition?’

If cognition does not cognize,
It would follow that even wood is a cognition.
Without a nearby cognizable,
I would definitely call that ‘not cognizing’.

‘It is the same thing that cognizes form.’
Then why would it not also hear at the same time?
If it is because no sound is nearby
Then there is also no cognition of it.

How can that which has the nature
Of sound perception perceive forms?
A single person might be called father and son,
But his intrinsic nature is neither,

Just as lightness, activity and darkness
Are neither father nor son.
Nobody has ever seen
Visual perception with the nature of sound perception.

‘Like an actor, it assumes different characteristics.’
If it sees, it is not immutable.
‘It just appears differently.’
Such singularity is something unprecedented.

‘Its different characteristics are not real.’
Then describe its true nature.
‘It is cognition itself.’
Then it would follow that all beings are one.

Sentient and insentient would also be one
Because they are equal merely in being existent.
If the instances are delusions,
What common basis could they have?

Something insentient is not the self,
Because of its very insentience, like a vase.
Because of its possession of a mind,
If it then cognizes, it follows that its non-cognition has been eliminated.

‘The self has not changed.’
Then how did it become sentient?
Thus, being non-cognizing and free from activity,
Space would also be such a ‘self’.

‘If the self does not exist,
A connection between actions and results is illogical.
After performing an action, it is gone,
So, for whom could there be karma?’

It is established for both of us
That action and result have different bases
And that a self does not have any role in this.
So, is your objection here not pointless?

‘The causal agent is the recipient of its result.’
No one ever sees this happen.
It is just in dependence upon a single stream of being
That the so-called ‘agent’ and ‘experiencer’ are taught.

The past and future minds are not the self,
Because they do not exist.
If the arising mind were the self,
Then when it ceased, there would be no more self.

For example, if you split apart
The trunks of banana trees, nothing is found.
Similarly, if you search for it thoroughly,
You will find the self to be no more real than this.

‘If sentient beings do not exist,
For whom should we have compassion?’
Compassion is for those who appear out of confusion:
They are accepted for the sake of the results.

‘If there are no sentient beings, who gets the results?’
This is true but, nevertheless, they are accepted out of confusion.
For the sake of fully pacifying suffering,
One should not oppose the delusion of these results.

Confusion about the self increases
Pride, the cause of suffering.
‘There is no way to resolve this [contradiction].’
The meditation on non-self is supreme.

The body is neither the feet nor calves,
Nor is it the thighs or waist,
Abdomen or back,
Chest or shoulders,

Ribs or hands,
Joints or cavities,
Internal organs,
Head or neck.
What is this body then?

If this body is present as a whole
Among its individual parts
Then part of it consists in each part,
But where is the thing itself?

If the body consists of a complete whole
In the hands and so forth,
There would be as many bodies
As there are hands and so forth.

If the body is neither inside nor out,
Neither within the hands and so forth,
Nor apart from the hands and so forth,
How does it exist at all?

Therefore, out of confusion, we think there is a body
Where there is none.
It is like thinking a heap of stones is a person
By some particularity of its arrangement.

While the conditions are assembled,
The body will continue to appear as a person.
So, while the hands and so forth exist,
A body continues to appear.

Similarly, what more is a hand
Than a collection of fingers?
These, too, are collections of joints,
Which have their own distinct parts.

Even parts have distinct particles,
And those particles have distinct areas.
Even these distinct areas are not without parts;
They are like space. Therefore, not even particles exist.

Accordingly, who could make this analysis,
And still have attachment to dreamlike forms?
When there is no existent body,
What is a man and what is a woman?

If suffering exists in reality,
Why does it not prevent joyfulness?
If there is happiness, why are those afflicted by pain and so forth
Not made joyful by sweetness and so forth?

‘It is not experienced because
It is overridden by the stronger force.’
If something is not experienced,
How can it be a sensation?

‘The suffering exists as a subtlety
When its coarseness has been removed.’
If this implies it is something other than suffering,
Then, whatever that is, that is what this ‘subtlety’ is.

If suffering cannot occur
Due to the arising of its contrary condition,
Shouldn’t such suffering be considered
Merely the attachment to a concept?

Because of this, meditate upon
This analysis as the antidote.
The meditation arising from
This field of examination is the food of yogins.

If an intermediary connects sense organ and object,
Where do they make contact?
If there is no intermediary, they are unified.
So, what has contact with what?

Particles do not impose upon other particles,
For they are identical in having no capacity.
Without imposition, they cannot combine.
Without combining, they cannot make contact.

‘They make contact despite being partless.’
How does this make any sense?
Making contact with something partless:
When you see it, will you show me?

It is illogical to make contact with
Consciousness, which is bodiless,
And likewise for anything composite, because it is nonexistent,
As was analysed previously.

If there is no real contact,
What are these sensations arising from?
Why go to all this trouble?
What could be harmed by what?

If the one who senses
And the sensations themselves are nonexistent,
Once this has been seen,
How could craving not be dispelled?

Even what is seen or touched
Is itself dreamlike and illusion-like.
Sensations are not perceived by mind,
Because they arise simultaneously with it.

Although something from before may be remembered after,
That is not the experiencing of it.
A sensation cannot experience itself,
Nor does anything else experience it.

There is nothing existent that experiences sensations.
Therefore, there are no sensations.
Therefore, what could ever harm
This selfless composite?

Mind does not dwell in the senses,
Nor in forms, etc., nor somewhere between these.
Mind is neither the inner nor outer,
Nor is it found anywhere else.

It is neither within the body, nor apart from it.
It is not combined, nor is it something distinct.
Because such a thing does not even slightly exist,
Sentient beings are by nature nirvāṇa.

If the cognition exists before the cognizable,
What does it arise from?
If cognition is co-emergent with the cognizable,
What does it arise from?

If it exists after the cognizable,
In that moment, what does it arise from?
Accordingly, all dharmas
Should be understood as non-arising.

‘In that case, there is not really any relative arising,
So how can there be two truths?
If the relative exists for the Buddha due to others,
How can sentient beings transcend suffering?’

The relative is just the discrimination of those other minds.
It is not the Buddha’s perspective.
If [the effect] is ascertained as arising after [the cause], it exists as relative.
If not, it does not have even relative existence.

The understanding and its analysandum
Are mutually dependent.
All analysis is expressed
In dependence upon accord with consensus.

If at that time there were an analyst
Analysing the analysis
Then there would be an infinite regress
Because that analysis, too, would have to be analyzed.

However, when the analysandum has been analyzed
Then that analysis has no basis.
Because it has no basis, it is non-arising.
This is also called ‘nirvāṇa’.

In that case, the existence of this pair
Is a reality that is extremely difficult to maintain.
If objects are established from the sense powers,
What supports the existence of the cognition?

‘Cognition is established from the cognizable.’
Then what supports the existence of the cognizable?
If they are in mutual dependence,
Then neither one exists.

If there is no father without a son,
Where does the son come from?
There is no father without a son.
Accordingly, neither of them exist independently.

‘When a sprout comes from a seed,
We acknowledge the existence of the seed.
Since cognition arises from a cognizable,
Why do you not acknowledge the cognizable’s existence?’

When it is acknowledged the seed exists,
That cognition is independent of the sprout,
But what independently acknowledges the cognition
Comprehending the cognizable?

Worldly ones directly see
Everything temporal has causes.
Differences such as in the segments of a lotus
Are produced by different causes.

‘What creates the different causes?’
They come from previous different causes.
‘Why is a cause able to produce its effect?’
It comes from the power of a previous cause.

If Īśvara is the cause of beings,
Please explain what the temporal Īśvara is.
If you say, ‘the elements’, that is fine,
But why trouble yourself over a mere name?

Furthermore, since the earth and so forth are multiple,
Impermanent, inanimate, not deities,
Suitable to be trodden on and impure,
They are not Īśvara.

Space is not Īśvara because it is inanimate.
He is not the self because that was refuted previously.
Since it is inconceivable to describe
A creator who is inconceivable, what would be the point of trying?

What could he want to create anyway?
Do you not claim that the self, the earth, etc.
And even Īśvara’s own nature are sempiternal?
Cognitions arise from cognizables,

And beginningless happiness and suffering come from actions.
So, what is it you say he has created?
If the cause has no beginning,
How can the effect begin?

How could his creations not be sempiternal,
When he depends upon nothing external?
If there is nothing that was not created by him,
What could he depend upon?

If he were dependent, the occurrence conditions
Would be the cause, not Īśvara.
When assembled, he is powerless not to create;
When absent, he is powerless to create.

If Īśvara creates without wanting to,
He is affected by an external power.
If he creates only when he wishes, the effect depends on his wishes.
How then is he ‘The Almighty’ [Īśvara]?

For those who assert sempiternal particles,
The refutation was completed previously.
The position of the Sāṃkhyas is that
The cause of beings is a permanent, primal substance.

Its qualities are ‘purity’, ‘activity’ and ‘darkness’.
While they remain in equilibrium,
They are called the ‘primal substance’.
Manifestations are said to be their disequilibrium.

A triple nature that is also singular
Is illogical. There is no such thing.
The three qualities also do not exist
Because each of them would also have three parts.

Without the qualities, the existence of sound
And so forth also becomes extremely implausible.
Nor can the insentient, such as cloth,
Contain pleasure and so forth.

‘They are caused by the substantial bare elements.’
Wasn’t the analysis of such substances already completed?
Also, the pleasure and so forth in the primal substance were your causes, not the bare elements.
Cloth and so forth do not arise from pleasure and so forth.

Rather, pleasure and so forth arise from cloth and so forth.
Apart from this, there is no pleasure and so forth.
Sempiternal pleasure and so forth
Have never been perceived.

If pleasure and so forth are essentially manifest,
Why are they not experienced?
‘They become subtle.’
How can something gross also be subtle?

‘It becomes subtle by the elimination of the gross.’
Then the gross and subtle states are both impermanent.
In this way, why not accept
That all such things are impermanent?

If the gross state is nothing other than pleasure,
It is evident that pleasure is impermanent.
‘Whatever does not already exist
Cannot arise because of its not existing.’

Although you deny that manifestations can arise
From their nonexistence, you also assert it.
If effects abide in their causes,
To eat food would be to eat excrement.

For the money you spent on cotton, you should have instead
Bought cotton seeds and worn them.
‘The worldly fail to see it due to delusion.’
Yet, someone who knows the reality is in the same predicament,

And since that knowledge of reality exists even for
The worldly, why do they not see it?
‘The worldly do not have valid cognition.’
Then their seeing of the manifestations would also be untrue.

‘If valid cognition is deluded,
Are your analyses not false?
If reality is emptiness,
Meditation for the sake of it is unreasonable.’

With no connection to an object of examination
There is no grasping of its nonexistence.
Therefore, whatever the false object may be,
Its nonexistence is clearly false.

When the son dies in a dream,
The discrimination that ‘he does not exist’
Counters the discrimination that he exists,
Even though it is false.

Therefore, on this analysis,
Nothing exists without a cause,
Nor abides in its conditions,
Whether individually or combined.

Nor does it come from other,
Nor stay, nor go.
This is what deluded ones take as real,
But how is it different from an illusion?

Whatever manifests by illusion
And whatever manifests by causes,
Examine from where it could come
And to where it could go.

Whatever it is, it is seen only in relation to something else.
Otherwise, it is not seen.
It is fabricated, like a reflection.
How can there be reality in that?

For something that already exists,
What cause does it require?
And if it does not exist,
What cause does it require?

Even a billion causes
Cannot alter nonexistence.
How can a state of nonexistence be existent,
Or become existent?

If its existence is impossible during its nonexistence,
When could it ever become something existent?
While its existence has not yet begun,
Its nonexistence has not yet been lost.

If its nonexistence has not been lost,
It is impossible for it to exist.
Nor can the existent become nonexistent,
Because it would follow that it would have two intrinsic natures.

In this way, there is no cessation.
Nor is there any existence.
Because of this, all these beings
Are forever neither arising nor ceasing.

Dreamlike beings,
When analysed, are like banana trees.
In suchness, there is no distinction
Between nirvāṇa and non-nirvāṇa.

What is there to gain and what is there to lose
Of things which are, in this way, empty?
Who exists to respect me,
Or to despise me?

Where do happiness and suffering come from?
What is there to be joyful or miserable about?
When I try to find reality itself,
Who has craving and what is there to crave?

When analysed, what lives in this world
And what can die in it?
What can arise and what has ever arisen?
What friends or relatives are there?

All is like space.
May we come to fully understand this.
For those who want happiness,
The causes of conflict and excitement

Create intense disturbance and hysteria.
We are tormenting, fighting and arguing with one another,
Cutting and stabbing one another.
By such nonvirtues, we endure great difficulties.

Having enjoyed so much happiness,
In happy rebirths again and again,
After death, it ends, and one suffers,
Falling into torment for a long time.

Within conditioned existence, there are many precipices,
For there is no truth in it.
Where there is conditioned existence, there is no reality,
For they are incompatible.

There is no way to truly exemplify
This unending ocean of unbearable suffering.
It is where we lack strength.
It is where life is short.

It is where we are worn out, striving to live and get by,
Where we are exhausted by hunger and sickness,
Where we sleep and where we cause harm,
And where we meaninglessly associate with the childish and with friends.

So life swiftly passes by without any meaning,
And a remedy is extremely difficult to find.
How can we find a way
To dispel habitual distraction?

It is where demons are striving to cast us
Into the great lower realms.
It is where overcoming doubts is hard
Among its many mistaken paths.

An opportunity like this will be difficult to find again,
And the presence of Buddhas will be extremely difficult to find.
It is difficult to escape the river of defilements.
Alas! The suffering just goes on and on.

Although the sufferings are intense,
Some cannot recognize their own misery.
Alas! It is only right to feel pity
For those who dwell in the rivers of suffering.

This is like, for example, bathing again and again,
And then stepping into a fire again and again,
Proclaiming one’s happiness,
While being in immense pain.

So, carrying on as if
There were no old age or death,
They are first subjected to death
And then fall into the unbearable lower realms.

When will I be able to pacify
These unbearable fires of suffering
With a rain of accumulated happiness
Falling from clouds of stored up merit?

Having fostered the non-conceptual
And devotedly accumulated merits,
When will I show emptiness
To those lost in conceptualization?

By whatever virtue there is
In my undertaking
To enter the bodhisattva conduct,
May all beings enter the bodhisattva conduct.

By my merit,
May all those in all directions
Afflicted with physical and mental suffering
Attain oceans of happiness and joy.

As long as they remain in saṃsāra,
May their happiness never fail.
May beings attain the uninterrupted
Happiness of a bodhisattva.

In however many hells
There may be in existence,
May all those living creatures
Have the bliss and joy of Sukhāvatī.

May those tormented by the cold find warmth,
And may boundless waters pour
From the clouds of bodhisattvas,
Cooling those tormented by the heat.

May the forests of razors
Become divine groves.
May the trees of Śālmari
Grow into wish fulfilling trees.

May the realms of hell become places of joy,
Covered with vast pools, fragrant with lotus flowers,
With calls of wild ducks, geese and swans
Resounding gently in the air.

May its burning pyres become heaps of jewels.
May its molten earth become a clear, crystal floor.
May its crushing mountains become
Celestial palaces of worship, filled with Buddhas.

May its showers of embers, burning rocks and fiery razors
From now on be a rain of flowers.
May the conflict of armed violence
From now on be a casting of flowers.

May those submerged in the torrents of hell,
Their flesh completely incinerated from their lily-white bones,
Attain, from this virtue, the bodies of gods,
And dwell among goddesses in gentle, divine rivers.

‘Why are the servants of the Lord of Death and his dreadful crows and vultures suddenly afraid?
Whose power clears away the enveloping darkness, bringing joy and happiness?’
When they look up, may they see the blazing form of Vajrapāṇi in the sky,
And the power of their intense joy clearing away all negativities, may they go to join him.

Seeing the glittering fires of hell
Extinguished by rains of flowers mixed with scented water,
May they wonder what could have brought such happiness,
And may these denizens of hell see Padmapāṇi himself.

‘Friends, come here quickly. Don’t be afraid.
He forcefully dispels all our suffering and brings the power of joy!
A protector of all beings, who has generated bodhicitta and kindness,
A blazing youth with hair in knotted locks delivers us from these horrors.

‘See one hundred gods offer their crowns at his lotus feet.
A rain of flowers falls upon his head, his eyes moist with compassion.
Thousands of goddesses sing his praises atop magnificent pavilions.’
Upon seeing Mañjughoṣa, may the denizens of hell cry out in joy.

By the roots of my virtue, may the denizens of hell,
Seeing the cooling, fragrant rains of happiness fall
From the stainless clouds of the bodhisattvas such as Samantabhadra,
Be filled with joy.

May animals be freed
From the horrors of preying upon one another.
May ghosts have happiness
Like that of the Northern Continent.

May their hunger be sated,
And may they always be bathed and refreshed
By streams of milk
Flowing from the hands of Avalokiteśvara.

May the blind see
And may the deaf hear.
May mothers give birth without any pain
Like Māyādevī herself.

May the naked find clothes,
The hungry find food,
And the thirsty find water
And delightful, refreshing drinks.

May the poor acquire wealth.
May the unhappy and miserable find joy.
May the distressed be placated,
And may they have confidence and stability.

Wherever sentient beings are unwell,
May their sicknesses quickly disappear.
May the diseases affecting every living creature
Cease and never occur again.

May those who are afraid be without fear.
May those who are bound be freed.
May the weak find strength
And may their minds be calmed.

May all those travelling abroad
Be happy wherever they may go and,
For whatever purpose they are travelling,
May they achieve it without any difficulties.

May all those aboard boats and ships
Achieve whatever they set out to do and,
Having happily returned to their own shores,
May they be reunited with their loved ones.

May those who have lost their paths
Encounter fellow travellers,
And proceed to their destinations with ease,
Unmolested by bandits, wild animals and so on.

May those who are lost and alone in wildernesses,
Children and the elderly without any protector,
Those who are unconscious, mentally disturbed or insane,
Be protected by the gods.

May they never lack the eight freedoms.
May they have faith, wisdom and kindness,
Eat appropriate food, have good conduct,
And remember their former rebirths.

May they have inexhaustible wealth
Like that of the bodhisattva Gaganagañja.
May they be able to do as they please,
Without conflict or violence.

May beings with little splendour
Come to have magnificent glory.
May those who are emaciated or ugly
Come to have radiant beauty.

May women everywhere in the world
Be reborn as men.
May the lowly achieve highness
And crush any arrogance.

By my merit,
May all sentient beings without exception
Abandon all nonvirtue
And always practise virtue.

May they never be separated from bodhicitta
And may they practise the bodhisattva conduct.
May they be supported by the Buddhas
And abandon the actions of Māra.

May all sentient beings
Have immeasurably long lives.
May they live in constant happiness
Where the word ‘death’ is never even heard.

Everywhere may there be
Gardens of wish fulfilling trees
Filled with Buddhas and bodhisattvas
And resounding with the delightful sounds of dharma.

Everywhere may the land be
Without stones, etc.,
Smooth like the palm of a hand,
And even like a lapis lazuli.

May many mandala circles
Of many bodhisattvas
Adorn the face of the earth,
Beautifying it with their natural radiance.

May all embodied beings
Continuously hear sounds of dharma
From all the birds, trees,
Rays of light and even space itself.

May they always meet with the Buddhas and their sons,
And with limitless clouds of offerings
May they pay homage
To the supreme ones among all beings.

May the gods bring timely rains,
And may crops be abundant.
May kings reign in accord with dharma,
And may the people prosper.

May medicines be effective
And may mantra recitation bring accomplishment.
May ḍākinīs and ogres
Have compassionate minds.

May no sentient being ever
Be in pain, practise nonvirtue,
Be afraid or abused.
May they never be unhappy.

In the monasteries, may reading
And recitation flourish and endure.
May the saṅgha always be harmonious,
And may they be firmly established.

May monks who wish to train
Find places of solitude and,
Abandoning all distraction,
May they meditate with peace of mind.

May nuns have material support,
And may they be free from conflict or danger.
May all monastics
Never let their moral conduct be damaged.

May the immoral tire of their ways
And may their nonvirtues come to an end.
Attaining a happy rebirth,
May their conduct never be impaired.

May the learned be respected
And find the support they need.
May their minds be pure
And may they be renowned in every direction.

In future lives may nobody experience suffering,
And may whatever they do be without difficulties.
May they quickly achieve buddhahood
With a physical form surpassing that of a god.

May all sentient beings
Make many offerings to all the Buddhas.
May their happiness
Be the inconceivable bliss of a Buddha.

May the wishes of bodhisattvas
For the benefit of beings be accomplished,
And may all beings have everything
The Protectors wish for them.

Similarly, may all śrāvakas
And pratyekabuddhas have happiness.

Until I have reached the ‘Joyous’ bhūmi,
Through the kindness of Mañjughoṣa,
May I remember my previous lives
And attain ordination.

May I live with simple food
And have simple needs,
And throughout all my lives
May I find perfect solitude.

If I ever wish to look upon him
Or ask him the slightest question,
May I see the protector
Mañjughoṣa himself, without any hindrance.

In order to accomplish the benefit
Of all sentient beings, as limitless as space,
May my conduct
Be like that of Mañjughoṣa.

As long as space endures
There will be living beings.
For that long may I remain
To dispel their suffering.

However they may be suffering,
May all their suffering ripen in me.
May the bodhisattva saṅgha
Bring happiness to the world.

May the teachings, which are the only medicine
For suffering and which are the source of all happiness,
Be honoured and respected,
And may they long remain.

I prostrate to Mañjughoṣa,
By whose kindness my mind turned to virtue,
And I prostrate to my spiritual masters,
By whose kindness I matured.
